ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to work in a lab and the skills to be successful in one.
How to present and write my own research
I gained skills in doing science research, thinking critically about my project, how to investigate a scientific question, and how to communicate science effectively.
I learned to create a plan for research and executed the research. I also learned to write scientifically
You develop as much research experience as you want. The skills range based on the lab but because it was a lot of remote work, I learned mostly image and data analysis.
Developed skills in independent biology research, writing a journal paper, making a poster, giving a presentation

I learned so many lab techniques (cell culture & asceptic technique, running agarose gel, RT-qPCR, DNase treatment, RNA extraction, Nanodrop quantification, etc.). I also learned a lot about planning experiments, data analysis, and presenting my work. I felt that my scientific writing strengthened quite a bit, and I made my first poster presentation through this project.

I learned how to perform intracranial neurosurgeries to implant windows into the skull. I also learned how to run MATLAB code and write some limited code. This was all integrated into a dark rearing method where we used these surgeries to enable live in mouse 2-photon imaging, and subsequent data analysis of signaling dynamics.
Research skills.
Developed my skills in the lab as well as in scientific writing.
I learned new lab techniques and how to operate in a professional laboratory setting. Really great experience, would have been even better without covid.
I learned how to code in R, some bash, and some python. I learned about how to design a computational project, and think on my own. I had a great research mentor who helped facilitate this process.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More guidance as to what is expected of us
Great opportunity to do independent research. I wished there was more interaction with classmates and the course instructors.

Strengths: I like lab research and always learn a lot about doing science when I work in the lab. Weaknesses: Absolutely no guidance from MCDB faculty on the proposals/write-ups. We never got feedback on our fall semester submissions. I already knew how to make a poster from a non-Yale research opportunity, and I used that to guide my poster making, but I had several peers have no idea of where to start because, again, MCDB gave us no guidance/instruction outside of two links to websites.
It's a great course. They do a great job of being flexible and allowing everyone to do their own work!

Strengths: great way to learn, I really like being able to apply stuff hands on rather than just take another lecture

weaknesses: nothing really

The strength of this course was the in-depth mentorship of my mentor, Dr. Nicolle Rosa-Mercado and PI, Dr. Joan Steitz. They really made the experience what it was, and I owe all the techniques and skills I learned to them.
Very good course.
I wish there were more ungraded checkpoints.
Solid, but there was little guidance, especially at the end. A clearer set of instructions as well as more regular communication with the lab course leaders would be appreciated.

Strengths: freedom for students to do research as they desire. 
Weaknesses: nothing major. It would be really helpful to have a centralized list of information regarding logistics of final project submission/presentations. I had to search through a number of emails for the info.
There is no feedback.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The presentations were all engaging despite new format
I liked the online presentations and poster sessions.

Very individualized, but for me i did everything remotely and it worked great, but this was really made possible by mentors who did an outstanding job. i know others who didnt have a great research experience this year
The virtual poster symposium went better than I had expected.
Everything was fine.
I'm not sure what to fix as my research wasn't terribly affected in the sense that I was able to go into the lab.
Having in person lab research was so great.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yeah, this is a good course if you want a taste of research. If you don't like research, you're better off taking the 1 semester senior thesis course. If you like research a lot, you should take the 20 hours a week version of this course.
Useful if you want to go to grad school
Yes, great opportunity to do independent research and gain skills in research and scientific communication.
You're taking this for the senior research requirement, so sure.
Yes if you need for credit!

Absolutely. A disclaimer though: I did my project remotely during COVID and so I had a VERY different experience than one might normally have. I really enjoyed doing research to learn, learned a lot, and ended up having a project I was very proud of, but my lab was also exceptional in making it a good experience. I think the single biggest factor in your experience is finding a good mentor, especially if there are still public health restrictions in the fall.
Yes! I think learning lab techniques and scientific thinking early on is really important for anyone interested in the life sciences.
Yes
Yes!
Yes! 10 hours is a sweet spot, I think 20 would have been too overwhelming for senior year

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Yearlong senior research
Thesis research, we had online presentations at the end. Had to complete work in our labs
All my research was done in-person, but all presentations for research were given virtually.
Remote senior thesis research project (computational biology project)
The research project was mostly conducted in the laboratory! There was a virtual poster symposium at the end of the year.
In person lab mixed with at home data analysis.
Virtual presenting.
Independent research under lab PI.
NA
